description: deutero- +‎ -ium. Coined by American chemist Harold Urey, from Ancient Greek δεύτερος (deúteros, “second”)

entries.meaning: (physics) An isotope of hydrogen formed of one proton and one neutron in each atom - 21H.
examples: Heavy water is "heavy" because it contains deuterium.
There were about 80 deuteriums for every million protiums, and virtually no tritium.
